about.description:
Xesco (Francesc Xavier) Mercé Balagué. Ivars d’Urgell (Pla d’Urgell, 1965).

Multidisciplinary artist. Graduated in Fine Arts from the University of Barcelona (1988). Founding member of the collective group of artists La Xina A.R.T. (1997) and the European network of contemporary art spaces Kanîbal’hopox (2008). He formed the performance duo "Deluxe" with Luis Casado. He is a drawing teacher at the Isabel de Villena School. He has been editor and director of the arts and essays magazine La Conxinxina. So far, he has held more than 50 solo exhibitions and more than 140 group exhibitions, in addition to numerous actions, installations, and public sculptures. His work has been exhibited throughout the country and the state, as well as in a dozen countries in Europe and Asia.

His artistic work covers almost all disciplines and techniques: from performance to poetry, through drawing and experimental music. According to Lucien Verneuil, his work "is halfway between poetry, irony, criticism (and self-criticism of art), experimentation, and social agitation." Art critic Joan Maria Minguet Batllori and historian Pau Minguet have written about him: "His work is a succession of outcomes, answers to new questions, and answers to questions that have existed for many years. Answers that are not sequential and that eliminate the previous ones, intertwining in a series of always provisional conclusions. He is an artist with the will to bring us to the question, to instability. Certainties always play in favor of power, he must think. Uncertainties invite the viewer to step out of complacency or alienation."

He has also published four books: 10 Mediterranean Artists in N.Y., 1998, Nineteen Hundred Ninety Ten, 1999, The Chemical Desert, 2023, and ´ (Closed Accent), 2024. He lives and works in Esplugues de Llobregat and in Ivars d’Urgell, where he has his studio.

new1.description:
Due to the heavy floods that have affected the province of Castellón, we have had to postpone the The Chemical Desert exhibition until the fall. I'm sharing the project presentation text so we can keep it in mind:

“Sooner or later, we all have to cross a desert. It may only be of domestic proportions, but it can also be of an abysmal magnitude. It may last just a bad moment, a bad day, or turn into a long season in hell. You can come out of it, more or less victorious, as Travis Henderson did in Texas or T.E. Lawrence, conquering Aqaba. But you can also get lost in it forever, like in a labyrinth of invisible walls, like the walls of Eryx. There are even those who, by their own will, venture into it to undertake a spiritual retreat or a mental fast and find there the question to all the answers.

I entered it in the fall of 2021, when I was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma, a type of cancer. After various journeys through several deserts, I am now near the edges, on a kind of deserted and gentle beach, combed by a soft sea breeze. It resembles a vast cinematic set or the beginning of a film by Carl Theodor Dreyer.

In the first spring of this strange journey, I began an uncertain project of drawings and poems. This eventually materialized into a collection of collages, which you can now see at Espai Nivi (in fact, the project could have been renamed “The Nivi Desert”), and into a book, which you can now read, if you feel like it.

The pretext I chose was the colossal attempt to organize chaos undertaken by a bearded sage named D.I. Mendeleev, creator of the periodic table. The 118 elements gave the title to each image and, as an acrostic, the base for each verse.

This literary and visual collection (a sort of strange logbook that follows no other logic than that of dreams) accompanied me throughout my journey and was, at once, oasis, island, or space station. I hope it serves as a navigation chart, perhaps inaccurate and incomplete, but mysteriously exciting, for your own future adventures through any of the deserts, oceans, or immense voids of the galaxy.
